Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An angry client is loudly criticising a cut moments before the salon is due to close.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story: I glanced at the clock—ten minutes to closing. My last client, Mrs. Evans, glared at her reflection, her voice rising with every complaint about her haircut. “This isn’t what I asked for! How could you get it so wrong?” she snapped, drawing the attention of the other stylists. My training as a hairdresser told me to stay calm, listen, and do whatever I could to make her happy, even if it meant staying late. But tonight was Sunday, and I’d promised myself I’d finally make it to church. I’d missed so many services, always putting work first, and I felt the weight of that absence in my heart. My faith taught me to honor commitments to God and community, to find rest and renewal in worship. Yet here I was, torn between my duty to a dissatisfied client and my longing to reconnect with my church family. My hands trembled as I reached for my scissors, caught between the demands of my profession and the quiet call of my faith.
